channel.title: OS discussion?
channel.description:
Like some knew, most didn't I haven't been active lately here. This came because I simply couldn't access mscp anymore, not via TOR, not chrome, not opera, not firefox. I don't know why.
[b]short story:[/b] I installed ubuntu as virtual machine since we use it at school, and I'm having exams for Linux (terminal). Thinking about mscp I saw that I could access via my vm, but it isn't really practical so I stayed away as well. I started to learn from school and own experience the beauty and power of Linux and started messing around with distributions. Ended up with Sabayon 10 which I completely fell in love with, which I also have as dual boot now and on it now.
How more I work with Linux how more I start to laugh with windows, now I have it dual-booted I'm going to be on it all the time and I'm going to get back active on mscp now I can access it again.
Now I've found a fitting distru for myself (Sabayon 10) I would leave windows behind if it wasn't that I still like to game. It's a fact that Linux is still behind if it comes to gaming, but for the rest Linux all the way!
What OS are you using and why not another one? Linux users, why did you switch to Linux, which distru do you prefer and why?
My fresh installed Sabayon 10 Linux distru [img]http://i.imgur.com/eBAox.png[/img]

item.title: OS discussion?
item.dc:creator: @CoonHunter CoonHunter
item.description:
@CoonHunter wrote:

I preceded lubuntu for quite a long time. All my computers are broke otherwise I would be working on finding other flavors still.

Read full topic

item.description:
@eyeownyew wrote:

Linux definitely will take over the gaming market… Don’t know if you’ve seen the statistics, but linux is remarkably better with OpenGL. It might take a while, but it will happen.

item.title: OS discussion?
item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

Kodiak:

A friend recommened linux mint to me the other day, i uninstalled my ubuntu immediately.

You should mess around with distru’s in a virtual machine if you haven’t yet.
I’ve tried like 20 distributions and was always like meh…
Until Sabayon, love at first sight.

Read full topic

item.title: OS discussion?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“Kodiak, post:12, topic:474146”]A friend recommened linux mint to me the other day, i uninstalled my ubuntu immediately.[/quote]Really the only thing mint offers is a different DE installed by default along with a lot more applications (installed by default). You can still get Cinnamon on Ubuntu or any other mainstream distro pretty easily.

Read full topic

item.title: OS discussion?
item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

[quote=“RSCShadow, post:9, topic:474146”][quote author=zyle1992 link=topic=592083.msg4183482#msg4183482 date=1355815783]

Give it a year or two, Linux will soon take over the gaming market.

Not until developers start intending to release games on the linux platform (and most of their existing user base is already on windows).

And I don’t think that WINE will be able to compete with an actual windows desktop for quite some time.
[/quote]I wouldn’t call WINE a competitor. It’s already doing pretty well with a lot of applications though.[/quote]

Depends, for popular distru’s like ubuntu it’s pretty easy to set up steam e.g. and works fine,
but like the one I am using, it’s a pain to get steam working. But that was before the open beta so I might try that now

Read full topic

item.description:

Give it a year or two, Linux will soon take over the gaming market.
[/quote]

Not until developers start intending to release games on the linux platform (and most of their existing user base is already on windows).

And I don’t think that WINE will be able to compete with an actual windows desktop for quite some time.[/quote]I wouldn’t call WINE a competitor. It’s already doing pretty well with a lot of applications though.

item.title: OS discussion?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

Ubuntu and Linux in general is a bad choice considering I develop .NET applications using visual studio and run mostly windows-exclusive software (inb4 WINE).
Not trying to force anything on you but I've heard great things about [url=http://www.mono-project.com/Main_Page]Mono[/url] and [url=http://monodevelop.com/]MonoDevelop[/url]. Some great programs like Banshee were made for Mono and that was the default media player on a version of Ubuntu.

As for Linux gaming, Steam’s recently been ported and is currently in open beta.

Read full topic

item.title: OS discussion?
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Windows 7. XP has compatibility issues and I can’t record music with the software I use. 8 sucks ass and is just counter-productive to a any sort of software engineer. Ubuntu and Linux in general is a bad choice considering I develop .NET applications using visual studio and run mostly windows-exclusive software (inb4 WINE).

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

Anything with XFCE, lately its been Xubuntu. Had a kick where I liked Openbox but it quickly faded. Been through Arch, Debian, and Fedora, but none of them stuck as well as Xubuntu

item.description:
@Travas wrote:
